(d) denies Australia's lowest paid workers any further wage increase unless their award is stripped of basic entitlements such as long service leave, superannuation and paid jury service leave;

(e) further removes workplace and enterprise bargaining from the protection of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, placing it solely in the hands of the Office of the Employment Advocate, which is run by one the Minsters former senior personal political staffers;
(f) further weakens opportunities for employees to organise and bargain collectively;
(g) aggravates problems of inequality for women and the most vulnerable in the labour market;
(h) further restricts workers who are denied proper industrial protection in their state from accessing federal protection;
(i) prevents the Australian Industrial Relations Commission from conducting much of its traditional conciliation role;
(j) further dismantles the framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes;
(k) amends the termination of employment provisions to limit an employee's right to pursue an application and extends the cost provisions;
(l) emphasises the punishment and prevention of industrial action rather than its resolution;
(m) unduly hinders the entry and inspection of premises by relevant organisations;
(n) demonstrates a lack of balance in freedom of association provisions;
(o) fails to ensure that Australia's labour standards meet our international obligations; and
(p) has a short title which is deliberately misleading and fails to represent the actual intention and impact of the bill; and

(2) the House also condemns the Government for its eagerness in tabling a bill that will specifically strip workers of their basic rights while failing to protect workers' legally accrued entitlements in cases of corporate insolvency; and
(3) recommends that a new bill be introduced which:
(a) delivers fair and equitable outcomes for Australian workers;
(b) preserves basic conditions for all Australian workers;
(c) provides for an independent commission with the appropriate power to conciliate fairly and settle disputes; and
(d) provides jobs and income security.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise to address the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . I say at the outset that I will certainly not be supporting the pious amendment of the member for Brisbane. This is the end of a century. We began this century as a new Federation, having given to the federal government, versus powers of the state government, the right to intervene and regulate industrial relations matters where a dispute arose which traversed the boundaries of one state to another.

speech.para: Over the last century our industrial relations and workplace relations practices have evolved, as have our laws, but it was only really in the late 1990s that we saw very major amendment to the way we operate and practise in this country. When I first came to Australia in the late 1960s and early 1970s we had a situation where the employment market was dominated by a multiplicity of craft based trade unions and management was dominated by autocratic British management practices. Sitting in the middle between employer organisation bodies and organisations of employees called trade unions was the Industrial Relations Commission.

We had what has been known euphemistically as the industrial relations club between employer bodies, unions and the AIRC, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which attempted to regulate all manner and all matter of relationships between employees and employers. As we tore down the wall around Australia with respect to our trade practices in the 1980s and early 1990s and as Australia retreated from isolationism and opened itself up to the world, we have also finally started to modernise our antiquated and highly regulated industrial relations system and practices.

The bill before us today, entitled `More Jobs, Better Pay', meets the commitments of the coalition's responsible offerings to the public in the 1998 election campaign. In lieu of the four items that the member for Brisbane talked about, there are some eight items I want to positively talk about very briefly on this legislation. Workplace agreements are the primary focus. The legislation will retain the right of limited protected action but requires secret ballots. I want to talk about the award system and the AIRC being retained but renamed and modernised, voluntary mediation services, the compliance framework being tightened, unfair dismissals, small business and its place in the workplace relations environment, and voluntary membership and increased accountability.

Workplace agreements in the form of both Australian workplace agreements and certified agreements are absolutely the primary focus of this comprehensive legislation. Award simplification means minimum regulation. In contrast to the statements by the member for Brisbane, the desire of the legislation is to reduce from awards those ridiculous conditions which have been there for so long and to simply leave the awards as stripped-out basic provisions underlying employees' entitlements and where the bulk of their wages and the bulk of their agreement with their employer on working conditions is made up by agreement which the two arrive at together—not as opposites, but together.

Over the life of this government since the 1996 March election we have reduced industrial confrontation very substantially in this country. As Bill Kelty said, instead of World War III, because the coalition won and it wanted to start deregulating the labour market, what we have seen is a reduction in industrial confrontation, a reduction in strikes and lock-outs and greater industrial peace and harmony and therefore increased productivity and increased real wages for Australian workers—increased real wages, not reduced wages. And we want to continue that process. We want to absolutely continue that process.

Whilst talking about not simplifying awards, I well remember the time I visited Robe River. One of the requirements of that basic award at Robe Iron was five flavours of ice-cream in the staff canteen every day. If there were not five flavours of ice cream, then everybody went home. That was a great award provision, wasn't it? Let us retain that for the next 20 or 30 years. That will sure help us. That is a great one. We should have picnic day ensconced in awards. What we need in awards are things like a basic rate of pay, holiday pay, long service leave—and that is about it.

The second point is that we should retain the right of limited protected industrial action, but it is the intention of this legislation to guarantee workers their independent right versus their union bosses—that is, the right of a secret ballot before they strike. I am one who has believed in secret ballots for a very long time. I have seen the destruction that occurs to workplace relations. I have seen the destruction that occurs in attitudes between employers and employees when the union bosses come to town and say, `Look, regardless of the fact you're getting on with the boss, we're going to make you go on strike because you should have better pay or you should agree to this set of conditions that we at union hall say you should. If we say you should, you have to do it.' That is wrong. This bill will provide for secret ballots, an issue for which I have long lobbied.

The award system in the AIRC will be retained, but the AIRC will be renamed as the Workplace Relations Commission. It is about time we changed the name. As we are changing the culture and the attitudes, let us change the name as well. It is not a matter of stripping the commission of its powers. In fact, what it is really about is providing voluntary mediation services instead of all this compulsion. Why do we need the compulsion that went with the club? We do not have the club anymore. We are trying to break down the club. I wish we could in the building industry in Victoria, but that is another matter I will get to. Voluntary mediation services are a very desirable mechanism and are far more preferable to the compulsory service of having to front up to the commission and having to pay the lawyers, the barristers, the solicitors—the lot. Let us pay for all that.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 5.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to raise some concerns I have about some of the candidates running in the Wollongong City Council local government elections on Saturday week. I find it quite disturbing to think that we have such an array of individuals pretending to be what they are not.

speech.para: We have Daniella Reverberi standing for the Liberals as the mayoral candidate. I thought the Liberals were a bit more choosy. This is the same Daniella Reverberi who stood against me for the Greens, stood against me for the Democrats and, of all things, stood as an Arkell Independent for a local government election once in the past. Her husband, Chris Illert, has stood against me for the Greens when his wife was standing for the Democrats, stood against me for the Democrats when his wife was standing against me for the Greens and is now standing for the Liberals again. No wonder they are in strife in New South Wales when they have to go to these sorts of lengths to find candidates.

We then have Mr Nick Brash standing for the Active Community Team. He represented the Marijuana Party in the Senate election. We have Philip Williams, who stood against me for the Liberals in 1996, who is standing as an Independent for the council elections but who is on the same ticket with Daniella Reverberi, who is standing for the Liberal Party, who used to be a Democrat, who used to be a Green, who used to be an Arkell Independent. Then we have Alan Ackhurst standing as an Independent in another ward, but he ran against me for the Liberal Party in 1998, ran against David Campbell for the Liberal Party in Keira in 1999, but somehow he has now become an Independent.

It does not end there. We also have another mayoral candidate Mr Alex Darling who is running on a ticket in ward 3 with Pat Franks. They are both sitting councillors. But Alex Darling is running as the businessman's candidate for mayor. I understand that Pat Franks and Alex Darling have had a huge falling out because Alex Darling has decided to swap preferences with the Active Community Team's candidate David Martin—no relation, thank goodness.

Why do I say that there are some concerns about that? Because the Active Community Team are the group of individuals who have two members on the Wollongong City Council who have voted down every bit of economic development opportunity that has ever come to the city of Wollongong. These are the people who represent the other end of town—not only the community activists that they hide behind but they certainly are a front organisation for Paul Matters and the South Coast Labour Council. It is Paul Matters, the puppet master, who will control David Martin, Kerry Christian and all these other so-called Active Community Team personnel who are running for Wollongong City Council. He is the man behind the mask.

What have we seen from these people? They have voted down economic development opportunities such as a new five-star hotel for the Illawarra. Standing behind this facade of being green to the core, they voted down an inquiry into the Illawarra escarpment to protect it. When the Labor members of the Wollongong City Council voted in favour of it and it was carried out and then the decision was brought down, David Martin went out and claimed it as his own and said it was all his own work and he was in favour of it all the time.

I have real concerns about Wollongong City Council falling into the hands of David Martin and the Active Community Team. The council of Wollongong, which has been led by David Campbell and the Labor Party for the last four years, and by David Campbell and the Labor Party for the four years before that, have actually returned Wollongong City Council to being debt free. Under Labor they have reversed the circumstances of the Frank Arkell led Independents of the years before.

We have David Martin and the Active Community Team putting out scurrilous rubbish in a newspaper called The Link. They do not put their name on it. They run scurrilous stories containing absolute garbage about the Labor lord mayoral candidate, saying that he is going to be disbarred as a lawyer. All through this newspaper there are articles from the Greens and the candidates running for the Active Community Team. They are running outrageous stories about others trying to stop economic development opportunities at Port Kembla, such as a new copper smelter and so on.

They are hiding behind the facade of being green, of being in favour of jobs, of being in favour of everything that is bold and beautiful. When it comes to thorough analysis you have to say, `Labor in the past; Labor in the future.' Under George Harrison's team, Labor will deliver jobs to the Illawarra, jobs to Wollongong and jobs through the Wollongong City Council. He will build on the fine work that has been done by David Campbell and the Labor team over the last four years. I say to the people of Wollongong, `On Saturday week do not be fooled by David Martin. Have a look behind the facade that is there and you will see Paul Matters the puppet master.'

talk.start.para: —I would like to congratulate the Queensland Country Credit Union for opening a branch at the Rode Road Shopping Centre in Stafford Heights. It has been a very sad time for the shopping centre. Three major banks have pulled out of that shopping centre in the last five years. I have spoken to the residents and the businesses on a number of occasions. The banks pulling out had an absolutely devastating effect on the district. Initially, discussions were held with the Bendigo Bank. They went on for a considerable time. It was wonderful to see the Queensland Country Credit Union taking up the challenge and setting up last week. The community now has a bank that is a focal point.

speech.para: The member for Werriwa and the member for Grayndler were on the Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration with me. I must thank them for the work that they put into the report entitled Regional banking services: money too far away. When I first sat in on this committee, I thought this issue just affected banks in regional areas and that credit unions and the Bendigo Bank were going into regional areas. I realised the devastating effect banks pulling out also has on local communities, particularly city communities. It has just as devastating an effect in those areas as it does in the regions.

The manager of the Queensland Country Credit Union, Joanne Wilkinson, said that many shopping centre tenants have already supported the credit union and they have established new accounts. `I think the banks are making a terrible mistake,' said Mr Radowski, who has been a butcher in the area for a number of years. Older people are having to get on buses and do their banking elsewhere. That takes away business from the shopping district and also the community spirit that banks and other facilities provide.

The response to the opening of this particular community bank has been absolutely overwhelming. Up to half the tenants of the shops in the area recently signed up to new accounts. In fact, I understand that the other day there was a huge queue of people waiting to sign up. The shopping centre manager has welcomed the opening and she has reported a renewed interest in the shopping centre. Many of the residents and the business people have switched accounts from other banks. Having a credit union again will certainly revitalise this part of my electorate. It is also a problem that is faced by another part of my electorate—the Redcliffe Peninsula. In Margate the same thing has happened. In the last four to five years the three major banks have pulled out of Margate, and I have seen a steady decline in the business activity of the area. Margate also has a largely older population, and they are having to travel further. A lot of these people cannot drive and have no means of transport.

I attended a seminar today on older banking clients. It was presented by the Commonwealth Bank to our committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration. I must commend them on some of the steps they are taking, but nothing beats personalised banking. There is a genuine fear of using flexitellers, particularly amongst older members of the banking fraternity who have been loyal to banks like the Commonwealth Bank for 50 or 60 years. Sometimes they feel that their loyalty has been betrayed by the increasing bank charges and closures of bank branches. We must never underestimate the devastating effect that that has on older members of our community. When I was elected one of the first functions I had to attend was the closing down of the local branch of the Commonwealth Bank. It was a very quick lesson in how devastating the closure was, because a number of the people at the function had banked with the Commonwealth Bank for a number years. It was a very emotional thing.

I commend the credit unions and the community banks for their effort in taking up the slack where the major banks have, at the moment, left off. I also commend them on their low fee structures and the great work that they are putting in to ensure that all Australians have access to low-cost and easy-to-operate accounts.

talk.start.para: —The relationship between the government and the Democrats gets curiouser and curiouser day by day. Today Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 9) 1999 was introduced into the parliament. The second reading speech says, in part:

speech.para: An inadvertent consequence of the passage of the overall package of amendments to the modified ANTS Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme is that the forestry and timber processing industries would have been required to pay approximately 8c per litre more for off-road use of fuel than other agricultural industries. The intention of the government was always that these industries would receive the same rebate amount. The amendment contained in this bill ensures that this commitment is kept.

That is not true. The Prime Minister, in the statement he released with much fanfare outlining the grubby deal that he had done with the Democrats in relation to off-road diesel and light fuels, said:

The extension to the off-road concession for diesel and light fuels will be limited to providing full credits for marine use, bush nursing homes, hospitals, nursing homes, aged persons' homes and private residences, but not for construction, power generation, manufacturing or forestry.
Not forestry, and yet they said here today that it was always the intention of the government. The Democrats were quite clear on this. The West Australian on 13 July stated:
Democrat Senator Lyn Allison said the move meant Mr Howard was reneging on an integral part of the deal made to secure Democrat support for the GST in the Senate.
We have the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry saying, as did the Prime Minister:
This was not the intention and we always wanted to extend this concession to forestry.
It is quite clear that that was not the case in relation to the deal done with the Democrats.

What we and all Australians need to know is: are the Democrats complicit in yet another deal? We are seeing deals within deals. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is saying we are doing some secret deal with the Democrats on youth wages when we are not, and yet they may well be doing deals with the Democrats—or they are trying to `blind side' them, to use a phrase that the Prime Minister used, as reported by Laurie Oakes today, in relation to the issue of an apology to Aboriginal people. The Prime Minister is saying, `Wow, we're very noble. We've come up with a great arrangement with the Democrats,' yet he goes into the party room and says, `This is all about blind siding the Labor Party.' So much for the Prime Minister's nobility and his lofty ideals. They are exposed as a political manoeuvre by the Prime Minister. We now have to ask: is he blind siding the Democrats in this case or have they done yet another grubby deal behind the scenes and sacrificed the last remaining principle that they could possibly have? If so, they have sacrificed everything in the process.

Is this a question of a dirty diesel deal done dirt-cheap? Is that we are seeing today? Is what we are confronting a dirty diesel deal done dirt-cheap? I heard a song used in this place today. Are they `Slippin' and slidin' and playin' dominoes', as Neil Young sang in `Harvest' in the early 1970s? There is a lot of slipping and sliding going on around here, and we need to know. Why doesn't the government come to us, the opposition, if they want to talk about this issue? Let's sit down and have a talk about it instead of blind siding the Democrats or doing dirty diesel deals and doing them dirt-cheap. Let us have some principle, some integrity, in this parliament instead of these grubby deals and the parading of lofty ideals when they are nothing but cynical politics—as when the Prime Minister refused to apologise to the Aboriginal people of Australia. Let us get some integrity into this parliament. Let us get some integrity into the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and the Prime Minister. Let us expose these dirty diesel deals done dirt-cheap. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Ovine Johne's Disease: New South Wales

talk.start.para: —On two occasions now I have raised concerns in this House about the way in which the New South Wales government is handling the serious issue of ovine Johne's disease and, more specifically, the impact that heartless decisions made by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture are having on struggling fine-wool growers and sheep producers. I would like to quote to you from a copy of correspondence dated 4 August 1999 which I have received from two constituents, Mr and Mrs Gorham of Frogmore. The letter is addressed to John Evers, Veterinary Officer of the Rural Lands Protection Board, and supports all of the arguments that I have been making in the past about the handling—or mishandling—of the OJD affair.

speech.para: The correspondence centres on the Tout family of Gundagai, who members of this House would be aware have suffered the personal loss of their son Warrick in the tragic canyoning accident in Interlaken, Switzerland, that claimed 14 young Australian lives. It seems that the government and its departments do not think the Touts have suffered enough. I begin with the second paragraph of that letter:

Bruce Tout's property at Gundagai, which was managed and operated by his son Warrick, has had restrictions placed on it due to 5 month old merino wether lambs being sold to the Tout property from our subsequently declared OJD property.

It has been brought to our notice that Mr Tout has had 2 separate lots of tests, 450 sheep tested in August 1998 and 450 sheep in February 1999, with all of these tests negative to OJD. After representations to Dick Jane (chief veterinary officer NSW Agriculture), Mrs Marilyn Evers (senior field veterinary officer) Don Saville, (Chief of division of Animal Industries), Ian Roth (program leader animal health) and NSW Farmers the trading restrictions still apply to his property.
I understand from a Tout family member there may be a need to sell the above-mentioned property that has been managed by Mr Warrick Tout.

I feel there is a sense of despair and frustration, a black cloud has been hanging over the Tout family for 18 months. Mr Tout is at present in Switzerland identifying his son. I believe his property produces an income but injustice has swept it away.

This property is being continually tested for a positive diagnosis. We would suggest that this property with 900 sheep tested possesses less of a risk factor than all the other untested properties trading freely or indeed the nearby residents who have tested 50 sheep and have been given license to say `I'm free'. Why should this property be compromised when enough clean sheep have been tested to allow Bruce Tout to be accredited MN1 status under the Market Assurance program?
We suggest you use your considerable influence to prevent this family from being defrauded of their true property value. They have suffered enough.

That is precisely the point that I have being continually bringing out in this place about the amateurish way in which the handling of the OJD problem has been inflicted on innocent people. There are other matters associated with the OJD problem in that letter. It referred to the `shooting and pitting of 2,500 sheep on a Harden property' supervised by the veterinary officer that the letter targets. It says in another place:

Men and Women who have placed their trust in Agricultural bodies set up to inform and support them are seriously talking of suicide as a solution to the problems these agencies have caused them. As one affected producer you diagnosed said to me—
to the writer of the letter—
`I sat on the doorstep and cried for two days. I could have shot myself and everyone around me.'
Another very discouraging comment made in the letter was:

At a time in history when the price for a medium wool clip is $3.00 per kilo the farmers ally, their advocate, their employed vet is putting such restraints on them that their already ailing cashflows are devastated.

Mr Deputy Speaker and members of this House, that is the reality of what is happening with this nonsense that has been perpetrated on the ovine Johne's disease control program. I want to reinforce to the House that I am going to continually raise this until such time as commonsense prevails to stop the heartache and stress that are being created as the result of overzealous members of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and their veterinary officers creating these massive problems for people who are struggling to maintain a livelihood.

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General's intervention at question time on 12 August, the last day of the last sittings, marked an official end of the most determined and unprecedented campaign by government to damage a political predecessor. The government and the Liberal Party are absolutely obsessed with Paul Keating and his political legacy. Mr Keating not only opened up the Australian economy, broke the back of inflation and doubled the country's capacity to grow but also championed the cause of a multicultural country, a republic integrated with Asia, at peace with its indigenous people—in short, a record this government despises.

speech.para: The Liberal Party, knowing they cannot pulp Mr Keating's record, tried to pulp Mr Keating himself. After eight years of attack in the parliament on Mr Keating's financial interest in a piggery, the government then turned their attack on Mr Keating through the media. A major assault was mounted, using and abusing Kerry Packer's 60 Minutes program. 60 Minutes spent several months, on its own admission, preparing its assault on Mr Keating, employing his discredited former business partner, Mr Constantinidis. To dress up its smear and make it look respectable, 60 Minutes then called on the government to establish a judicial inquiry into the allegations.

The next day at question time, the Attorney-General said that the government, meaning Mr Howard, had asked him to tender advice on whether there was any basis for the allegations. We found out three weeks ago from the Attorney-General himself that there was none—no truth whatsoever. Not even Mr Keating's worst enemies, the Liberal Party of Australia, could establish the grounds for any sort of inquiry.

So what did these eight years of political attack and persecution amount to? As I have only a few minutes, I will deal with the most serious—the `cover-up' as 60 Minutes called it, the claim that Mr Keating used his high office as Treasurer and Prime Minister to cajole the Commonwealth Bank into absolving Mr Constantinidis of certain private debts in return for Mr Constantinidis signing a deed releasing Mr Keating of any obligation to him. The whole charge was without foundation. The Commonwealth Bank denied it the day following the program in March.

The Commonwealth Bank did settle certain private debts with Mr Constantinidis without any benefit to Mr Keating. But the key point was that this was done in July 1998, over two years after Mr Keating had left the prime ministership. By then, Mr Keating was a private citizen and the Commonwealth Bank was completely privately owned. No question of conflict could ever have arisen, even if Mr Keating had secured a deed of release from Mr Constantinidis, which he did not. The charge, quite simply, was an outrage.

Paul Lyneham—the Benny Hill of the parliamentary press gallery—fronted the 60 Minutes programs. He slaked in one performance whatever credibility he had acquired over a lifetime in journalism, and he was made up like Mae West for the occasion of the destruction of his own reputation. Earlier this week his 60 Minutes colleague Richard Carleton put hundreds of Australian lives at risk in East Timor. Mr Lyneham put the truth at risk plus his own reputation. If a politician had been caught out so badly there would have been calls for him to resign. At the very least, Mr Lyneham should now stick to his song and dance routine and leave serious journalism to serious journalists. 60 Minutes has left to it only the John Laws alibi: they are in fact entertainers, not journalists.

The final slur in this matter came from the Attorney-General on 12 August, clearing Mr Keating of any wrongdoing while trying to smear him in the process. As Michelle Grattan said in the Sydney Morning Herald two days later:
As for the idea Keating should act to clear his reputation—that is outrageous coming from an Attorney General. Guilt, not innocence, has to be proven.
Let this be the last word on this sorry saga of political vindictiveness by this small-minded and narrow government, led by such a small-minded and narrow Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to address a matter that has been much in the news in my electorate of late, namely, the question of nuclear waste storage. But before I address that issue, I put the question to the House: why does the member for Lilley continue to insist that the files that were found are Centrelink files when they are clearly not so? The answer to that is beyond me.

speech.para: For some days now, the media in the Kalgoorlie electorate have been on a feeding frenzy regarding the question of nuclear waste storage. As the member for Kalgoorlie, and federal member for the largest and most sparsely populated electorate in the world, the media felt I would have a point of view on having nuclear waste stored in this electorate. Numerous interviews were carried out and a process of selection took place whereby the public opinion that resulted was that the member for Kalgoorlie supported a push by a company called Pangea for the storage of waste deep underground in the electorate of Kalgoorlie. This is clearly not the case. When considered in their fullness, my statements would clearly indicate that that was not the case.

The process of storing nuclear waste deep underground in a geographical mass referred to as Pangea is, with today's technology, the most satisfactory and long-term safe process for the storage of nuclear waste. I believe their proposition is to store such materials in corrosive-proof containers that would be able to be inspected on a regular basis. In exchange for this privilege, they would provide great wealth which could be converted to public infrastructure.

However, when asked whether I supported the question of storage of waste in Western Australia, I answered, `One may never say never.' In a changed world, in different circumstances, the people of Australia and specifically Western Australia, and even more specifically the electorate of Kalgoorlie, may be keen to take a decision to agree to the storage of nuclear waste deep underground. The circumstances I outlined were briefly these: in a political state where nuclear waste was destroying the world environment as we know it, and Western Australia was under the threat of a drifting radioactive cloud, and world leaders from an environmentalist point of view were collectively begging Australians, specifically Western Australians, to agree to storage of nuclear waste in the most geologi cally stable and, hopefully, the most politically stable continent on earth, the people of Western Australia just may have a different point of view.

Because of that, I suggest that we must not at any stage adopt a head in the sand point of view. We must accept that we live in a dynamic world—from a physical sense as well as a political sense—and that our point of view today may not be the point of view we hold tomorrow. It is perfectly clear in my mind that a political group of any persuasion would not condone today, in today's environment, the storage of nuclear waste in Australia on behalf of the globe. But if the global population is threatened we may have a point of view which is distinctly different.

In closing, I repeat my question to the House: why on earth would the member for Lilley continue to claim that those found files came from Centrelink? Why on earth would he have the public of Australia believe that was the case when it is demonstrably not so?

talk.start.para: —In the short time available, I rise to respond to the extraordinary statements of the member for Kalgoorlie who in response to a request from the Minister for Community Services comes in and attacks my colleague the member for Lilley, who has put on record in this House the fact that over 100 files were found in a dump bin in Brisbane. The fact is: we put questions to the Minister for Community Services over a number of days and we did not have any answers. And he has the hide to come in here and ask questions of the member for Lilley. It is up to the Minister for Community Services and the government to respond to this issue.

speech.para: After question time today, the Minister for Employment Services made a statement that they were CES files—as though that made it better and that that was the issue. The issue is privacy. The issue is the failure of this government to protect the privacy of clients. The issue is the failure of these ministers to even talk to each other. It is up to the member for Kalgoorlie. He came in here and, in the middle of a speech on nuclear waste dumps, said, `It's okay because they were only CES files.' I do not think the clients think it is okay.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may continue until 6.10 p.m.

—I thank the member for Grayndler for raising this important issue because there is an important issue at the moment regarding what the member for Lilley has done in misleading this parliament. I would like to raise some key points. The first point is that the member for Lilley came in here on Wednesday after he and the member for Dickson had obtained those files. They knew about this on Monday morning. He came into this parliament and talked about privacy and yet it was his office that went through those files. Indeed, even in his press release he said that he went through them meticulously and `audited' them. Talk about tampering with people's files and the matter of privacy. The member for Lilley, aided and abetted by his female accomplice the member for Dickson, did that. He then came in here and claimed that I misled the parliament. That is definitely not the case.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I take offence at that and I ask him to withdraw it.
—I am listening closely. I am not conscious of an unparliamentary remark having been made; otherwise, as you know, I would require him to withdraw it.
—The minister said that I tampered with files. I did no such thing. I take offence and I ask him to withdraw it.
—The member for Lilley has not raised a remark that is deemed to be unparliamentary.
—The member for Lilley specifically said, even in his press release, that the files were `fully audited'.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I seek your guidance. As you are aware, I am the person on House duty tonight and my point of order goes to the normal courtesies and procedures of this House. Would it normally be the case that, if a minister were going to make a statement which raised questions about his shadow minister, he would have the courtesy to notify the shadow minister or to notify the person who is on duty in the House? I was here with the member for Adelaide. Nothing was mentioned whatsoever about this. We were not consulted. You got the member for Kalgoorlie—

—The member for Grayndler will resume his seat. I indicate to the member for Grayndler that the issue he has raised is not in any way covered by the standing orders and, therefore, it does not warrant any intervention by the Speaker.

—I noticed in the press release attachment that was put out by the member for Lilley that on Tuesday, 31 August the documents were audited by his personnel. When the question was asked on Wednesday about whether I was aware of this, I was aware that some SSAT files seemed to have gone missing, because I was contacted by the media on Monday. After going back to that media organisation, our investigations were hampered because we were not given any further information. Unbeknownst to me, the member for Lilley and the member for Dickson actually had that information. They misled the House because they should have provided that information to my office—or, indeed, to the government—on Monday.
—They were found in a car park.

—No-one wants to see privacy documents in incorrect places, whether they are in wheelie bins or anywhere else, and that is a very serious matter and we certainly take that on board, no matter what government agency it is.

speech.para: The clear facts here are that, in a press release issued this day, the member for Lilley claims that I misled the House. That is clearly not the case because he actually had the information. He went through it, audited all those 101 documents—and, if there is any dispute about privacy, it should be about the privacy breach of the member for Lilley. He is more interested in publicity than he is in privacy. This is an absolute disgrace because he actually had those documents.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I understand that the member for Richmond has accused someone of misleading the House. As you know, that requires a substantive motion. It cannot be made in any other speech. I suggest that you pull the minister into line and have him put an appropriate motion.
—If I had heard the member for Richmond accuse someone of misleading the House I certainly would.
—He said that the member for Lilley had misled the House. That, as you know, is out of order.
—It is a fine line. I remind the member for Newcastle that the practice of the House has been to require people who deliberately mislead to withdraw. That was not used in this instance.

—The point I was making was that that was one of a number of points that the member was making which are, in fact, substantial matters which require a substantive motion to be moved and which cannot be used indirectly in other forms of the House. I suggest that you advise the member either to bring it back as a substantive motion or to desist in what he is doing.
—The Minister for Community Services is well aware of his obligations not to move material that belongs in a substantive motion. If he were to do so, I would correct him.
—Also, what the member for Lilley did intentionally was to mislead the House and, through his further press releases—
—The minister has in fact—
—Point of order—
—I wonder if the Speaker might be allowed to rule before he hears the point of order.
—If I can have a win without making the point of order I will be very pleased.
—The minister has just, in that instance, done the very thing I cautioned him against doing. I call the minister.
—In his press releases and in his questions to the House, the member for Lilley claimed that there were breaches of Centrelink privacy when, clearly, these documents did not belong to Centrelink.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the minister said that the member for Lilley intentionally misled the House. You called him to order and he kept on with the same comment.
—I am reluctant to interrupt the member for Newcastle but, clearly, having called the minister to order on that matter—
—He then kept on talking about how he had misled the House.
—The member for Newcastle is making a frivolous point of order. I will not allow the minister to intervene. I require the member for Newcastle to resume his seat and I call the minister.

—What concerns me is that the member for Lilley set out deliberately to scare the 6.1 million Centrelink customers—many of whom are the most frail and vulnerable people within the community—when he fully knew, because his office did an audit on the files, that the files did not belong to Centrelink. But he did not let the truth ruin a good story. He deliberately set out on a tack to besmirch Centrelink.
—Are you going to tell us what was in the documents?
—No, you tell us because you had them and you audited them and you gave them—
—The minister knows that he has an obligation to address his remarks though the chair.

—The point is that the member for Lilley and the member for Dickson had these documents and they sat on them for 2½ days before they brought them to the attention of this House. The facts are that the member for Lilley knew that they did not belong to Centrelink. I did not know because they were in his possession. We were tipped off by the media that there were some files. I instructed my department to investigate the matter. As it turned out, they were not Centrelink files.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the minister is abusing the standing order which makes provision for ministers to extend debate. We appreciate that there are standing orders that provide that, but they are clear. Standing order 48A(f) says:

interjection.para: (f) a Minister may require that the debate be extended—
. . . to enable Ministers to speak in reply to matters raised in the preceding adjournment debate . . .
That is, if someone comes in and attacks the minister he has a right to reply.

talk.start.para: —I will hear the Manager of Opposition Business but I expect him not to abuse the—

—I am just trying to explain why I think this is not properly within the circumstances of 48A(f). It specifically says to `reply'. I know that the member for Kalgoorlie raised this issue, but he did not raise it in the circumstances of—

—With great respect to the Manager of Opposition Business, he may not be aware of the fact that the matter was also extensively raised, understandably, by the member for Grayndler, and it was in response to that that I allowed the minister the call.
—So all this is in response to that contribution by the member for Grayndler. I am just clarifying what I understand you are ruling on.
—The Manager of Opposition Business has heard the ruling and will resume his seat.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I do appreciate that.
—Mr Speaker, on a different point of order: I draw your attention to the state of the House.

—I have no intention of recognising that point of order and, in the interests of every parliamentarian, I simply declare the House adjourned until 12.30 p.m. on Monday, 20 September. I hope that will be borne in mind next time.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —We have seen a good victory this week for coalminers in Australia and particularly for the Oakdale coalminers who have been through a fairly long and difficult struggle over the past couple of months. They have achieved a concession from this government to get access to their entitlements that were lost when their company went into liquidation earlier this year. The miners in my electorate will see this for what it is, however. They are very pleased that their colleagues are going to be getting the entitlements that are rightfully theirs but they know very well that it is not the source of any great joy for this government that they are actually doing the right thing. They have had to be dragged kicking and screaming to this.

speech.para: The fight is not over for many workers in Australia. The bill that came into the parliament the other day is a very narrow piece of legislation that addresses the problems of the Oakdale miners. However, there are still many workers in Australia who now see this as a major issue and are wondering what will happen when their company goes bust or they become the victims of some kind of corporate restructure and they find themselves without their entitlements.

When I think of this, I think in particular of workers in my own electorate who have suffered this fate—the workers from St Andrews Hospital in Rockhampton and Yeppoon. On 20 December 1997 the bank foreclosed on that hospital and 157 workers were locked out of the hospital—their own workplace—by the bank as part of that liquidation. Five days before Christmas we had 157 workers in my town out of a job and wondering about their future. Not only were they out of a job; they missed out on close to $1 million of their own employee entitlements. At the time that that happened and up to today they have had no protection for those entitlements. The only option that they have had to date is to pursue the matter within the common law court system, which takes a long time and is very costly. Luckily these workers have the support of their various unions and that is the course they are pursuing. The trial date is not set down until November this year—almost two years from the time that they lost their jobs as a result of this company's insolvency.

The government has done the right thing somewhat reluctantly this week by addressing the problems of the Oakdale miners. However, the job is not done. We need to have a proper scheme in this country to protect employee entitlements to the full extent of those entitlements, not some kind of safety net. This money belongs to those workers and they are entitled to have it to cushion the blow should they lose their job due to company insolvency. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to take this opportunity to report back to the House on the tremendous response in my electorate of Forde to the historic motion this government passed last week in the interest of national harmony and true reconciliation. As I spoke to local residents in many parts of my electorate over Friday and the weekend, I was moved by the genuine and heartfelt support in the community for the Prime Minister's motion. Many people, some of whom I know have felt indifference or even reservation towards the process of recon ciliation in the past, are now receptive and much more open minded about the need to achieve agreement and consensus between all Australians.

speech.para: Last week's motion did much to reduce the `them' and `us' feeling which grew under the previous Labor government, creating a divide that worked against the cause of true reconciliation. While I do not pretend that last week's motion provides an all encompassing solution, I believe it is a vital step forward. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs inquiry into indigenous health, I have travelled to many Aboriginal communities in remote areas and witnessed first hand the living standards of many indigenous Australians.

I know it is a crucial priority for the Howard government that we achieve real improvements when it comes to basic things like health, housing and education. I am pleased that the motion we passed last week acknowledged the need for practical assistance to improve the lives of indigenous Australians as well as symbolic gestures to heal the wounds of the past. I am just profoundly disappointed that the Labor Party did not put party politics aside and join with us in the spirit of unity and national interest that the motion was put.

Labor chose to play the politics of division once again. The people in my electorate certainly did not thank them for it. In stark contrast, the local residents to whom I spoke over the weekend expressed a very high regard for Senator Ridgeway's sensible and uniting approach. I see, in the community's respect and admiration for him, a genuine way forward for all indigenous Australians. He has done the cause of reconciliation and national unity a great service, and every Australian can be thankful for his achievements so far. I am sure Senator Ridgeway will continue to play a constructive role in the continued negotiations that are ahead of us.

The positive reaction I received from the people of Forde over the weekend mirrors widespread community support for the motion. This has been evident in various opinion surveys, in particular a phone survey in Queensland which showed that 90 per cent of those who responded agreed with the Prime Minister's statement. Once again, it is clear that the Prime Minister has acted in the national interest of Australians and, in doing so, he has provided a real sense of hope and optimism for a strong and united future for Australia.

subdebateinfo.title: China: Visit by Parliamentary Friendship Group

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on an issue raised by the member for Moreton in the House on 23 August 1999 concerning a visit by a delegation to the People's Republic of China. I was also a delegate, as was the member for Makin, who is in the chamber today. I am very concerned about the matters raised by Mr Hardgrave on 23 August. Whilst he certainly spoke highly of our growing friendship and trade relationship with China, when one actually goes to the text of what he said and reads what has been reported in the press, it seems to be suggested that our time spent in Tibet was actually as part of a human rights delegation. Mr Hardgrave made some fairly sweeping comments in the House, and I think anybody reading those comments might be entitled to assume that he was speaking on behalf of all of us, but he certainly was not.

speech.para: The delegation was actually part of a parliamentary friendship group. We were not an official delegation of the parliament; we were certainly not a human rights delegation. Whilst our time in Tibet was extremely interesting, and I think all of the delegates learnt a great deal, we were there as guests of the Chinese government. It is very important to put on the record that, whilst we did not witness any direct examples of human rights abuses, we could not, under the circumstances in which we were there, expect to have witnessed such events.

It was quite misleading for Mr Hardgrave to suggest that we could in some way attest to the improving human rights situation in Tibet. I feel very strongly that the issues we raised on a number of occasions with Chinese officials and with officials of the Tibetan Autonomous Region were indicative of the fact that a very large problem still exists with respect to human rights. In particular, when questions were asked about political prisoners and what actually constituted offences which would allow the Chinese government to arrest and imprison Tibetan citizens, the officials were very hesitant to answer any questions, and they did not provide any satisfactory answers to the concerns we raised about the Panchen Lama and the return of the Dalai Lama.

I would like to record on my behalf—not on behalf of any of the other delegates—that it was a very interesting and educative trip. I am delighted to see that the Chinese government is certainly interested in providing some support. One of the very good examples of what the Chinese and Australian governments are doing together is providing some humanitarian and health support in the Tibetan region. However, I have great concerns that there is a lot that we did not find out on this trip, and we could not have expected to. I think that the record must show that Mr Hardgrave did not speak on behalf of all of the delegates of that friendship group.

talk.start.para: —Today, I would like to take the opportunity in the short time available to me to read into Hansard an anonymous statement by a woman who is in hospital at this moment recovering from another of her many attempts at suicide. I thank my colleague Senator Brian Harradine for giving me this statement to read and for supporting this victim who is one of his constituents. She starts by saying:

speech.para: It seems everyone else has had their say on the film Lolita , from film producers, actors, politicians, journalists and `free speech' advocates. But the view of the incest survivor has not been sought or voiced.

I have been following the debate over the film, not like the majority who hypothesise from a purely intellectual stance, but from my own personal experience of having had Vladimir Nabokov's novel used as a tool in the sexual abuse I experienced in my childhood.

Lolita has run like a subtext through my life. As a child I read the book and lived a life not unlike hers. My stepfather had me play the role of Lolita to his Humbert—he even asked me to wear the pigtails and the ponytails. This man internalised the language and the philosophies of the writer, referring to me as his `nymphette' and inferring that I was his lover. In my puberty he handed me Nabokov's book with the advice that it would help me to understand the nature of our covert relationship and that I might identify with Lolita. The truth was he identified with the abuser and wanted to transfer his notions to me.

My stepfather's abuse of me involved brainwashing which convinced me that I was somehow to blame and which allowed intercourse to proceed unhindered for six years. Reading the book horrified and depressed me. I now consider it a form of intellectual child pornography.

Now things have come full circle, with Lolita back in the cinemas. For years I had blocked out her memory and gone about my life in a mechanistic fashion. But there is only so long a memory will remain sealed and silent. Soon it will contaminate everything. The novel/film will never cease to affect me because of the way in which it interplayed in my life. Lolita never got to say how it was for her and no-one wanted to know. As a child, she did not have the capacity to assign a meaning and language to what she could not understand.

The book has been described quaintly as a "tender tragic love story." Surely this can't be the same book I read: the book that involves an older man lusting over eight and ten year old little girls, gleeful at the death of Lolita's mother because this gives him unrestricted access to molest her daughter, drugging Lolita in order to have intercourse against her will when she is twelve and then pursuing a sexual relationship with her for the remainder of her childhood.

In the book, Humbert claims that by the age of fourteen, Lolita was letting him have sex with her. One wonders what happened in the intervening years. The coercion and force that would have been employed is conveniently omitted.

Likewise, my stepfather censored my view of the world and his own. I did not even know there was such a thing as what we now refer to as child sexual assault. The only paradigm I could place my experience into was that of the married couples I had seen in the 40's, 50's and 60's movies I was permitted to watch.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I wish to use the short time available to me this morning to thank a number of people who assisted me on a recent visit to Broome. I travelled to Broome originally at the invitation of Peter Tannock, the Vice-Chancellor of Notre Dame University, which has a campus in Broome. I had the pleasure of meeting Sister Pat Rhatigan, the Director of the Broome campus; the Chancellor of Notre Dame University, Terry O'Connor; and a number of the other governors who were visiting at that time. I had the pleasure of meeting Father Bill Miscamble from Notre Dame in Indiana, who is also on the board of governors; and I met Sister Clare Aherne, who is not only a very good teacher at Notre Dame University but a very speedy walker on the beach at Broome.

speech.para: I also thank the students who provided us—the governors and visitors such as me—with an introduction to the good work that Notre Dame University does at the Broome campus, especially in teacher education and in Aboriginal and business studies. Many of the students made the point that they probably would not have had an opportunity to study without Notre Dame University being present there.

We are also grateful for the hospitality of Steve Dean, the second-in-charge of the state Department of Education Services. Through the courtesy of Tom and Anne Stephens—Tom is the Labor leader in the Western Australian upper house—we were able to visit the Lombadina/Djarinjin Catholic School and met Sister Margaret Scott, the principal, and also Bishop Chris Saunders, although only briefly.

We also visited the One Arm Point Public School and met the Principal, Ron Pearson. Two of the young students, Nellie Bin Maarus and Nikita Balacky, showed us around. We had a chance to see one of the Croc Eisteddfod events—not the Rock Eisteddfod but the Croc Eisteddfod—and it was a credit to all the young students involved. We also visited the Sacred Heart School at Beagle Bay. Mary Jacquier, the Principal, showed us around the school and we also met Sister Shelagh and two of her students who are studying through Notre Dame University.

I would also like to thank Peter Yu and Pat Dodson and others who very kindly showed us around. In particular, Elaine Rabbit at Edith Cowan University gave us a very good explanation of the excellent work carried out by Edith Cowan in Broome. John Weichert, the Manager of the new Kimberley College of TAFE, is also doing an excellent job in providing training in areas such as aquaculture, horticulture, landscaping and IT training. To all these people and to others such as Paul Browning, I say: thank you very much for assisting me in learning about a number of indigenous and tertiary education issues.

talk.start.para: —The education, training and youth affairs backbench committee had a very interesting briefing on Wednesday morning from the Western Australian Minister for Youth, Mike Board MLA. An issue that is constantly raised with me in my electorate is the need for young people to be able to develop a sense of leadership and a sense of discipline. It is often said that national service should be imposed again, if not on everybody, at least on the young unemployed—this and/or compulsory service in the cadets. In Western Australia, they have taken the cadet idea to a new level. I believe that what they are doing has tremendous merit and I would like to share it with the House with a view to recommending a national scheme using the West Australian model as a pilot.

speech.para: Cadets Western Australia, as the program is known, still has the basic Army, Navy and Air Force cadets—which, as we know, has been in place for many years, and many successful graduates have set themselves up with this training. In addition to these conventional groups, new dimensions of training have been added in Western Australia for those with different areas of interest—for example, the Bushrangers for environmental care; the Red Cross, where the focus is on the elderly; the SES, where the focus is on the skills needed for firefighting, rescue and such; the police; and St John Ambulance, obviously concentrating on emergency health care.

In addition, organisers are also looking at setting up a unit involved in surf lifesaving and still water rescue. This is a community based program, not a school based one, although many schools participate in the running of the program. But, because it is a community based program and not a school based one, kids who are not at school are still able to access the program as well. In fact, these young people probably have more need of these skills than those who are still at school.

The idea of this program is to develop leadership and discipline in the youth of Australia while allowing them to have fun at the same time. Through this, young people receive a boost in self-image which some, though not all, need. In Western Australia, there has been plenty of media attention on this program, which has also boosted the image of youth throughout the general community. There are some common training components to all these different areas of cadets, but each area of interest has its own special training. Obviously, not all schools or communities could offer all the different types of cadetships. The idea is that young people be exposed to the training and discipline while doing something they enjoy. This will be much more readily accepted than forcing them into an activity which they do not have an affinity with.

Something that has been recognised more and more in the workplace is that people have an affinity for different types of jobs. The boss's likes, dislikes, strengths and weaknesses are often totally different from those of his staff. The same is true for students and it should not be a case of sport or nothing for extracurricular activities for them. The aim of this group is to get kids to do the best they can, even if it is not world beating. Much of the media attention these days is centred around the four per cent of youth who offend, while the 96 per cent who contribute valuably to society are often ignored. These programs, well administered as they appear to be in Western Australia, connect the youth with the general community and the elderly, especially through the Red Cross program.

Three hours a week is all that is involved in this program. The kids get the opportunity to experience a whole range of things. Private and business community groups have shown that they will get involved in such a momentous project. I am sure that we can all learn from what is going on in Western Australia, and I believe that the minister would welcome any approaches.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 30 June, on motion by Mr Bruce Scott:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 seeks essentially to do four things: firstly, to allow determinations to be made which will align the test for permanent incapacity for work for the invalid service pension with that for the special rate for totally and permanently incapacitated disability pension; secondly, to allow determinations to be made which will align the test for permanent incapacity for the income support supplement with that for the social security disability support pension; thirdly, to extend eligibility for the HomeFront scheme and introduce a home loan support program to provide loans for home maintenance and alteration; and, fourthly, to extend the Veterans' Children's Education Scheme to recipients of the extreme disability adjustment.

speech.para: I can indicate, from the opposition's perspective, that we will not oppose the passage of this bill through the House of Representatives. But I want to flag, for those who are interested, that Labor does have concerns about the bill. As a consequence of that, whilst we will not impede its passage through the House of Representatives, my colleague the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, Senator Schacht, will be pursuing these matters through the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. We believe that it is important that the veterans community has time to properly assess this bill before parliament decides whether to pass it or not. The committee hearings in the other place will facilitate that.

There is some concern about the question of the nexus currently between social security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Those on both sides of politics have argued for as long as I can remember that there should always be a separate Department of Veterans' Affairs and a separate department of social security in its various guises, even though some people could argue that, from an efficiency point of view, it is necessary to ensure that there is no disadvantage occasioned in the delivery of government services by the perpetuation of that particular state of affairs. Nevertheless, what we have seen in the main is agreement that the amendments being proposed are sensible—and I am delighted to see that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has entered the chamber—but there are some issues which we believe should be addressed through a Senate committee, and Senator Schacht will be pursuing those.

I therefore indicate that we will provisionally support the passage of this bill through the House of Representatives, but final support for the bill will be dependent on whether the veterans community supports the measures that are outlined here. The next opposition speaker in this debate will be the member for Cowan, Graham Edwards. He, of course, brings with him an incredible depth of knowledge of issues associated with the veterans community, and he will pick up on a number of these specific matters.

I take this opportunity to flag with the government, and with the minister directly, some other concerns, particularly those that the shadow minister for veterans' affairs has asked me to raise this morning. They are concerns that we are seeking some response to. The first is in respect of whether the government is addressing the request for extending the gold card provisions. I know this is an issue that has been around for some time, and I request the minister to enlighten us—including my colleague in the other place—on any progress in the matter.

My second question is: what has the government been doing to ensure that services will be maintained for veterans at repat hospitals now that the Commonwealth has handed over control of them to the state governments. I well remember that this was an issue when I had the honour of being the shadow minister for veterans' affairs in 1996, and it seems to continue to be an issue. It is certainly an issue in Victoria and has been raised in the House of Representatives, quite ably, in questions that have been directed to the responsible minister, particularly in respect of the Kennett government's manic decision to continue the process of privatisation in public hospitals.

My understanding—and the minister might like to address this—is that, when the decision was taken to hand over the Austin Repatriation Hospital in Victoria to the state government, there were some strings attached. At the end of one of those strings there was a fairly healthy wad of notes that went to ensure that veterans were not to be disadvantaged. The former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Con Sciacca, has suggested that on the end of that string was an amount which approximated $0.5 billion to ensure that the veterans continued to have a hospital facility in Melbourne that would meet their needs. Since the minister is here, he may like to address this particular concern, which many of us on this side of the parliament have, as I am sure others do. I am not talking about the philosophical underpinnings of privatisations of hospitals—or anything else—but about ensuring that veterans continue to have access to those much needed facilities.

My third question to the government is: what is actually happening to ensure that veterans are receiving from Centrelink the assistance they deserve, now that it has taken over the administration of many of the veterans' benefits. Underlying that concern is whether or not this government is going to continue with what has been pretty much a bipartisan policy in the past of maintaining two different departments. I know that the veterans community has always maintained that it feels far more secure knowing that there is a Department of Veterans' Affairs. But if more and more of the benefit paying mechanisms are going to other departments, under the umbrella of social security, community services or whatever it might be, it is a question of allaying the concerns which veterans might have.

It is important to give some thought also to the impact that the present cuts to the legal aid budget are having on veterans. Senator Schacht informs me that he has received a number of complaints on this matter. It is apparent that resources are no longer available through legal aid for veterans to access assistance when appealing unfair decisions by the department with regard to entitlements. If that is the case, it is regrettable. I raise that too with the minister as a genuine issue of concern.

I know the minister would appreciate that there is very much a view that most if not all issues in veterans' affairs are above politics. Certainly we tend to try to ensure that that is so. But when there are genuine concerns, we always reserve the right to bring them to the attention of the minister. The honourable member for Cowan, who will speak later in the debate this morning, is far better equipped, because of his very much hands-on approach to dealing with the veterans community, to raise more specific elements of these sorts of questions.

Finally, we are delighted that—as reported today in the media—medals of valour have at last been awarded to six very deserving Australians. It must be placed again on the public record that Labor had been pushing the former minister, Mrs Bishop, to act on this. Labor had been saying to her that there was a need for people to be recognised appropriately. It is not just an officer class type of thing. If serving men and women, defending this nation, are deserving of appropriate recognition, then they should be given that recognition. I am delighted that the matter has been addressed by this minister. I say to the minister that that is a welcome thing. I think it is fair to say that a lot of heartache could have been avoided, though, had his colleague who was previously in this position taken a little more notice of the concerns that had been raised on behalf of those very deserving Australians.

Let me conclude my contribution this morning by again indicating that Labor will not oppose passage of this legislation through the House of Representatives. The shadow minister for veterans' affairs has some concerns and would like to see the veterans community given some opportunity to make some comment on them before Labor finally determines its attitude in the other place. I have raised one or two questions on behalf of the shadow minister for veterans' affairs because of the concerns that many members on both sides of the House have probably been feeling in terms of representations being made to them by veterans. We look forward to the minister's response in his summing up in answering, hopefully, some of those questions. I wish this bill speedy passage through the House.

talk.start.para: —First of all, I offer my congratulations to all concerned in the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace, in particular to our Minister for Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer.

speech.para: The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 has been requested and approved by the bulk of the people to whom it applies. Usually it happens that people request legislative changes that they believe should apply to other people, but that is why it is so good working with veterans. The veterans I know are unassuming men and women who, whilst they are learning of their rights, only want that to which they are entitled. To illustrate my point: just last week I spoke to another veteran who was unhappy about the entitlement that someone else was getting, in his eyes, undeservedly. When I challenged him to give details, rather than talk in generalities he provided them within two days.

The story went like this: there was a serviceman who was married who later left his wife and entered a de facto relationship with another woman. After he died, his wife applied for and received the war widows pension. Unfortunately, she also died. Soon after, the woman from the de facto relationship changed her surname by deed poll to that of the serviceman. Six weeks later, she applied for and received the war widows pension and a gold card.

This is the kind of story that really outrages veterans. Benefits have been earned with blood and are not to be given or treated lightly. In fact, most of the work on behalf of veterans that comes into my electorate office consists of chasing up entitlements that have previously been unknown to them or for which they have never applied. Nine times out of 10, when asked why they had not applied earlier or why they had let their situation become so grim before asking if there was some possibility that they might have a little bit of help, the answer is, `Oh, there are so many people worse off than me and I don't want to take something away from anyone else,' or, `Other people probably needed it more than I did.' And isn't that interesting? The very people who gave the most for their country are unwilling to take away from it. Yet there are others who have no difficulty in working the system to take whatever they can get, whether they deserve it or not.

There are also people who have been allocated particular labels in the past which have stuck and which are, in a way, being used against them. This bill seeks to find a balance, because those on invalid service pensions really ought to, and should, be treated in that way, and those who are able to access other opportunities should be assisted to do so. Some may more appropriately be transferred to other avenues of financial support which allow and encourage the development of skills and perhaps a return to the work force.

This bill provides amendments in five major areas: the invalid service pension review; the extension of HomeFront; Home Support advances; the veterans' children education scheme; and the peacekeeping forces. There are several other minor amendments which decrease the inconsistencies and ambiguities in current legislation. This demonstrates the federal government's commitment to review legislation to ensure that it accurately reflects government policy.

Let me turn to the matter of determining eligibility for the invalid service pension. Service and veterans' groups have regularly expressed their disquiet to MPs, to the Department of Veterans' Affairs and to ministers about the ease with which some people seem to be getting the invalid service pension. On closer inspection, it became apparent that some people may have accessed this pension because of the lack of standardisation and objectivity in the criteria for applying the pension. This meant that, for some, this pension became a non-reviewable alternative to an unemployment benefit. As a result, the criteria used to access eligibility for the invalid service pension will now be standardised. They will also be aligned with Centrelink's criteria for accessing the permanent incapacity income support supplement to the disability support pension.

These criteria will then enable objective judgment of whether a veteran is permanently incapacitated and therefore eligible for the invalid service pension. This amendment will require a veteran to accrue 40 impairment points as set out in the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions, better known as GARP. Who would have thought that we would ever have legislation suggesting `the world according to GARP'! The veteran's permanent incapacity must be of such a nature that it prevents him or her from working more than eight hours a week permanently.

At this point, I hasten to add that totally and permanently incapacitated, or TPI, pensioners will not be reviewed. Veterans aged over 57 on 1 January 2000 will also not be reviewed. Veterans who already have 40 GARP points and who are unable to work more than eight hours a week will also not be reviewed. This is a matter of credibility, and most veterans contacted are pleased that these amendments will take place.

As was alluded to earlier, some veterans have been labelled wrongly, in that they can work, and it is appropriate that they do so. In these instances, it is more equitable that they be moved to income support programs which allow them access to training and vocational placement and opportunities. The review applies to 1,780 veterans, which is less than 15 per cent of invalid service pensioners, and it is totally supported by them.

HomeFront is the falls and accident prevention program that currently is offered only to war widows and veterans with a gold card. Through this bill, the federal government is extending the scheme to all veterans who are eligible for treatment from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This scheme is excellent, and any fall or accident prevented saves major costs—costs in terms of reduced mobility, families having to increase their physical support of the injured, loss of confidence and independence, not to mention any medical and hospital costs.

Under the HomeFront Program, people's homes are inspected for any potential gaps in their safety. You know the kind of hidden and familiar traps that I mean—that second bottom step that has been loose for years, that little ripple in the carpet near the piano, the verandah rail that is a bit wobbly, or that patch of lino that cracked after the house settled in the big drought. Those are the things that we walk under, past or over on a daily basis and we even regularly think to ourselves, `Yes, we must fix that one day.' These are the very things that can lead to simple accidents in the home that can have such horrific consequences.

Most of us know of someone who in their later years had a fall, broke a leg or a hip, spent a long time in hospital, came out and probably had another fall while trying to cope with their now weaker limbs and lack of trust in their body. Generally, the story goes that another even longer stay in hospital sees them emerge in a much debilitated state, not through the lack of care in the hospital but because of the enforced lack of movement and the associated consequences for independence. The old adage is: they were just never the same, they never came good again, or they died soon after coming home. If the extension of the HomeFront Program saves just one of the those accidents, it will all have been worth it.

This program does not end with the free home assessment. Financial assistance is also available to solve those minor potential safety problems. Up to $150 in any one calendar year is available towards the cost of recommended safety appliances and items such as grab rails or non-slip treatment of floor services. This financial assistance will go directly to the qualified contractor who is performing the work, so there is a further shell of protection for veterans built into this program.
